In this town on the e5th ult. by Rev. Mir. Stone. Edward D. n.insield, Esq. of Cincin- nati, Oh. son of Col. J. Mansfield, IL. D. of West-Point, to Miss Mary W. Peck, step- daughter OfDr Abel Catln.

 At Warehouse Point, William Barnes. Esq. to Miss Maria HOIkins, daughter of Joel Holkins, Esq.

 DIED,

 In Sharon, 96th ult. Mir Samuel Pardee. aged 81.

 In New-York, James F. Dana, MD. Pro- lessor of Chemistry in the College of Physi- clans and Surgeons in the state of fNew-York aged S4.

 In Cheshire, on the 24th inst. General An dre'C Hull, Marshal of the District of Conn aged 69. General H. has been long and ex- tensively known. and universally respected & esteemed by all who had the pleasure of his acquaintance. He was formerlyan frequent ly member of the General Assembly from the republican town of Cheshire, and during the late war was collector of internal taxes for this district.

 h Enfield, on the 18th inst Elam o. Pot ter, Esq. aged 54. A week before, he recei- we'd a slight wound in the inner part of the hand from a sickle, which, at the time gave him no alarm, but which on the 9th day follow ing occasioned severe spasms, and on the 7th terminated in a lockiaw.

SCOTTS FAMILY BIBLE,

 Sd Boston Edition, which will be sold at the lowest Boston pri- ces for cash or appoved credit. Hannah Moore's Works, vol. octave, with

 an excellent likeness of the celebrated au-

 thoress. and a view of Barley Wood"

 do. in vols duodecimo. Dwight's Travels. Cecil's Works. Jowett's Researches. Wolfs Journal. Opie's illustrations of Lying. Sherwood's Stories on Church Chatechism.

 do Lady ofthe Manor.

 do Stories and Tales. Contributions ofQ. Q. by Jane Taylor. Fosters letters and essays.

 do on popular ignorance Scott's Letters and Papers

 Sismondi's Literature of South Europe Johnson's works complete

 Plutarch's Lives. ,Crabb's Synonymes. Locks Essays. Bucks Theological Die. Rev Thomas Scott's Works. Chautabrian's Travels. Hopkins Divinity. Quarte, Octave, duodecimo, and pocket BI- BLES, common, extra, and calf extra binding. A genera! assortment of LAW, MEDICAL. CLASSICAL. and SCHOOL BOOKS. large supply of Ledgers, Jour- nals, and Day Books. A great variety of small books, suitable for

 Sabbath Schools, and presents for children. An elegant assortment of standard works, bound in superb style, suitable for "7'okens of Remembrdnce.'' Arrangements are made for receiving new works immediately after they issue from

 American Presses. >a Pen & Pocket Knives of the finest quality. Razors, famous Damascus blade Scissors, very superior article Quills, from cts to 62 1-2 cts per bunch Silver Pencil cases. Pocket Maps Table Bells. Wafer Stamps. Sand boxes, real I.ignumvite. do Tin. Gunter's Scale and Surveyors compasses. Together with almost every article in the Book and Stationary line usually found in similar establishments. Companies or private individuals wishing to purchase libraries, are invited to call anc examine the stock and prices before they go out of the county to trade. Country traders will be supplied with Walkden's Fine British Ink-powder, May nard & Moves do. Letter, Writing, and Wrapping Paper, and all kinds of School books as cheap as can be purchased in Hartford.

 Orders respectfully solicited, and books forwarded to any part of the county as cheap as though the purchaser were present to make his bargain. Litchfeld. May, 1897.
LITCHFIELD BOOK JUST RECEIVED, new supply of SCOTT'S FAMILY BIBLE,

from the two sections of the Pennsylvania ca- nal, and the canal along the Dclawarr, ou condition that the expense of the latter shah not exceed SIO,O0O a mile. The bill includes an appropriation of SI,2OO,0O0 thus year, to defray the expenses to be incurred.

This celebrated Powder needs no recom- mendation-every gentleman and lady should be in the constant use of it, if they wish to preserve their teeth from decay, and have them appear of a beautiful pearly whiteness. Price 25 cents box.

 Sold dy w. & s. BuEL and HENRY PHELPS.

 D. CLAY. November 21, 1926. eOw1y23

stitutiOnS tn New-England which have tho power of conferring medical degrees, and perhaps from the institutions in New-York and other States. The plan was proposed by the Medical Society of Vermont in 1925, and the object is to adopt meas ures for the improvement of Medical edu- cation.

 RcUOlMtiOm in Peru-A bloodleSS revo- lution has taken place in Peru, in which the Bolivian Constitution has been over thrown, the officers left in command dis placed, and the chief of them arrested to be sent home. Gen. Santa Cruz has pub lished proclamation convoking consti- tutional Congress for the first of May, to form Constitution adapted to the wants of the country, and to elect President and Vice President. The revolution was eff tected by the Colombian Officers, who e. lected Gen. Bustamento their commander in-chief

 The TOken.-Mr. S. c. Goodrich, of Boston, offers a premium of one hundred dollars for the best tale, and the same a. mount for the best poem, to be published in a Christmas and New Years Offer ing, for 1928, to be called The Token"

 Relief for he Grccks.-Portland and many other towns are walking up to the aid of the Greeks. The collections re- ceived by the committee in Boston, from the town and country, now exceed S11,- 900. A second vessel is expected to sail from New-York about the first of May, la den with supplies.

 Capt. Fr0nklin.-The last London pa- pers contradict a statement made few days previous, that Capt. Franklin had suc- ceeded in the object of his overland OK petition, and going on board tine Blossom sloop of war. No such intelligence, it ap- pears, had been received from the North West Company, or through auy other channel.

 Progress of steam.-A few year since the Paragon, then the swiftest steamboat on the Hudson, made her passage from Albany to New-York in twenty-seven hours, which was pronounced a "remark- ably short'' que now there are two boats on the river, which perform the distance in twelve hours. The New Y ork En- quirer says-' perhaps nothing can place in stronger point of view the velocity of these boats than the fact, that when they are at the top of their speed, and are go- ing in opposite directions, they will pass each other at the rate of a mile in two min utes, being a degree rarely witnessed even on race course !''

 The steamboat Tecumseh, arrived at Louisville from New Orleans in nine days and four hours, having lost one whole | night and part of another, by fog-dis- tance 1900 miles.

 1He Royal Family of Britam.-Mr. Hume calculated, lately, in the British house of commons, that the amount of the sums on the British pension list, to the different junior Branches of the roy- al family, was 934,OOO pounds sterling, in addition to the 100000 for the king.

 Journal of Paul Jones.-A copy of this | valuable. and interesting manuscript, in the best of binding and handsome writing, is now in Portsmouth, N. II. 1t was cop jed from the original by Paul Jones him. self, and presented to Louis XVI. on the 1st day of Jan. 17S6, as will be seen by re- fering to Jones' life, page 353; it is short- ly to be published, together with most cor respondence relating to our revolutiona- ry war.

 There is village in Essex co. NY. sit- uated on the river Au Sable, which emp ties into Lake Champlain, called Kees- vile, regularly laid out, with large cotton factories, iron works and other mills, and a population exceeding 1,5OO souls /! Five years ago there was no settlement at this then wild spot. The iron mines are pecu- liarly valuable. The country adjacent is covered with immense forests of pine. Russio.-An official account states, that in the four years from 1923 to 1926, 5O,- 9SO persons were carried of by extremely sudden death, in the Russian Empire :- 4,591 were murdered; 4,687 committed suicide. There were 664 robbers; and ,s4S criminals and vagabonds were ar- rested; 11,663 fires, by which 176 church. es and convents, 4,5O1 dwellings houses ill the towns, and 76,O29 houses in the country were reduced to ashes.

 An unkaown individual has presented the Evangelical Lutheran congregation of St. Jame's church, in New-York, with the church and three lots Of ground recent ly owned by the Irish presbyterian con-

had not presence of mind enough to avoid the calamity that was so near at hand, is not known. The warning appears not to have been to Capt. Mallory who was at the helm, and the disaster occurred in the man. ner that has been mentioned. Capt. Bun- ker immediately sent his boat, and several men, intending to tow the schooner to land but she filled so fast they had only time to save few articles before she went down. He then left the boat with Capt Mallory to enable him to pick up whatever might float from the wreck. Not the slightest blame for the disaster could be attached to Capt. Bunker, who did every thing he could to avoid it.--D0iLy Ado.

 BosToN, April 2l.

 Representative. ElectiOn.-A very full meeting of citizens without distinction of ancient parties, was held at Faneuil Hall last evening, for the purpose ofadopting measures for procuring d nomination of suitable candidates for representatives from this town, in the general Court. MT. w. Barry was chosen Moderator, and MT. John Lowell, Jr. Secretary. The meet ing was addressed by MT D. l.. Child, who proposed several resolutions for adop- tion, conforming in their general tenor and spirit with those adopted on former meete ing, and published in our paper on Thurs day. He was followed by MT. Bond, in a speech in favor of the resolutions and of the course proposed to be pursued. After some remarks by Mir. Clough, in which he urged the expediency of giving the most decisive support to the national and state Administrations, MT. Webster addressed the meeting in a speech of considerable length, in which he presented his views of the course which should be pursued by the electors of this city, in the present state of public affairs. The resolutions were unanimously adopted, and committee of S6 members, 2 from each ward, and 12 at large. was appointed, to form list of candidates as soon as the number shall be fixed by the City Council, and to report the same for consideration of future meeting.

 ACTIVE BENEvoLENcE "A horse, harness sed to chaise, twas observed during greater part of yesterday, tied at the lower end of Merchants Hall. Some passer-by, more con- siderate than the owner of the beast, towards night placed on conspicuous part of the har- ness the following label: "Wanted! Hotfa Peek of Oats. Inquire hin."-Boston Co,r- Ter.

 Another Warning to Sabbath Breakers.-On Sunday morning three young men took a small boat from the soop Patriot, at Spring street wharf, with the intention of proceeding on sailing excursion, but when they had reached about midway of the river, a sudden flaw capsized the boat,a Alexander Mackay, ,hn | O others were enabled to reach the shore. Mac kay has left widowed mother, ,who is incon- solable at the loss of her only son-a son too, who had been tenderly brought up, and who was urged, by all the tender ties of an affec- tiOnate mothei, to desist from his boat excur- sion on the Sabbsth. We understand that the last words of the mother to him were "AIexander, if you go this day shall never see you again. n.'-Com. Ado.

 Seuere Storms--The papers from various directions bring accounts of damage done by the late storms, and in some instances the loss olives. In Portland, Me. during the gale on the 18th inst. adOut 60 feet of the new part of the wharf was carried away. At Meeklen- burg Va. on the evening of the 10th, a storm was experienced, in which the hail stones were from the size of bullet to that of d hens egg. Much window-glass was broken. and the buds, &c. on the trees were beaten off. In the borough of Butler Pa. on Tuesday of last week, tree was blown acoss wag- on and caused the death of Mr. Newman, his wife and one child. 4 barn was blown down, and house unroofed. The same day about II o'clock, storm with rain passed through Beaver county, during which MT. Andrew Sands, two miles below BeavertOwn, wa. crushed to death by the fall ofa tree and MT John Alcorn. of Moon township, received severe wounds on his head and shoulders by the fall of limb.

 The Philadelphia papers mention that at the late session of the yearly meeting of Friends in that city, three thousand dollars were ap- propriated towards defraying the expenses of certain free people of colour from North Car olina. to Liberia, Hayti, and the free states,as they may prefer

 The American Trade with China last year amounted to $B,949, ,542, The commerce be- tween China and South America was double what it had been the year previous.

 At the Merrimack company's mils,in Low cit, Mass. eleven thousond yards of cloth $ Manut tactured daity most of which is printed for calicoes.

 The Editors of the Bostnn Recorder and Telegraph have issued proposals for publish Ing weekly paper for the special use oi " AI~1 Al

He planted four acres twOswith seed in iCs natural state, and two with seed soaked as above. Contrary to his fears, the lat- ter came up four days earlier than the for mer it was not injured in the least by worms or birds, while one half of the hills on the other two acres required to be plan ted second time. If the seed being im- Pregnated with the salts is not injured, if it will grow as well as seed not soaked-- the experiment can easily be made wheth- CT the salts will preserve # from birds and worms, by exposing quant;+y of it where worms, squirrels and birds can have access it. 1t is worthy an experiment of the kind, and we trust some of our agricultu- ralists will give it trial, for their own, as we'll as the public good.

 The severe cold with which we were visited on the first inst. is accounted for, from the fact, that the late storm was one of snow at the north. The papers inform us that the whole range of the CattskiIl mountains arc covered with snow to con- siderable depth. Cloaks are not usually needed on the first day of May ;-but this year few persons appeared to feel com fortable without one. We have reason to fear that this change in the weather from what it was three weeks since, will destroy peaches if not sundry other kinds of fruit.

 Fir.-The inhabitants of this quiet village were on Tuesday evening last aroused from their cosltations by the alarming cry of fire. This was an almost entirely new sound to a great majority of the citizens; for however it may be with other villages of similar size, which have engines to extinguish fire, and of course can afford to have them often, we, be- ing destitute of like safe guards, and depend ing solely upon Etna and Protection insur- ance policies, have heretofore. at least for several years, seen no larger flame than is made by a shaving bonfire But we have di- gressed; as above stated, there was on Tues day evening fire no less real than the burn ing of house. How it took fire is the ques- ton; Tuesday was d cold day, and had the tenement been inhabited by bipeds we might kaye concluded that the room had been over- heated to keep them warm; but such an expla- nation will not answer, for we are told that there has becn no fire near the building for several weeks except that which "levelled it with the dust" We must therefore conclude. that the said house possessed certain inherent ignitible qualities, winch kindly refrained from acting while it stood in the immediate vicinity of better buildings; but on its being removed to a new location, where it could burn without alarming its neighbours, it peace ably took itself out of the way. Damage,- to the owner SloO,OO.

 So great IS the dearth of news at the pres ent time, that after looking over fifty or sixty papers from different parts of the country, we can scarcely find sufficient suitable matter to fill our sheet. We seized our last New York and Boston papers. with eagerness, ho- ping to find two or three columns filled with "latest and important intelligence from Flu rope;" but here we were disappointed. No thing of importance is copyed from English and French papers. except the " Fashions for May," and sundry theatrical notices. How ever important such articles may he to the ci- ty gentry, we care not enough about them to induce us to read more than the caption, and take it for granted that our readers are some what likeminded. Fer want of more imme- diately interesting matter, the presidential question fills pretty large share of every i'm portant political paper; certain of these arti- cles we feel strongly inclined to copy, in or der to be in keeping with our contemporaries. The Morgan affair is by no means forgotten nor should it be until some of the darkness which surrounds it is expelled; but we live out of its influence, aud have ourselves said enough on the subject, until we can say MOrpa n iS alive n or tho r,onrdarors oc tt a

 Another Warning to Sabbath Breakers.-On Sunday morning three young men took a small boat from the soop Patriot, at Spring street wharf, with the intention of proceeding on sailing excursion, but when they had reached about midway of the river, a sudden flaw capsized the boat,a Alexander Mackay, ,hn | O others were enabled to reach the shore. Mac kay has left widowed mother, ,who is incon- solable at the loss of her only son-a son too, who had been tenderly brought up, and who was urged, by all the tender ties of an affec- tiOnate mothei, to desist from his boat excur- sion on the Sabbsth. We understand that the last words of the mother to him were "AIexander, if you go this day shall never see you again. n.'-Com. Ado.

 Seuere Storms--The papers from various directions bring accounts of damage done by the late storms, and in some instances the loss olives. In Portland, Me. during the gale on the 18th inst. adOut 60 feet of the new part of the wharf was carried away. At Meeklen- burg Va. on the evening of the 10th, a storm was experienced, in which the hail stones were from the size of bullet to that of d hens egg. Much window-glass was broken. and the buds, &c. on the trees were beaten off. In the borough of Butler Pa. on Tuesday of last week, tree was blown acoss wag- on and caused the death of Mr. Newman, his wife and one child. 4 barn was blown down, and house unroofed. The same day about II o'clock, storm with rain passed through Beaver county, during which MT. Andrew Sands, two miles below BeavertOwn, wa. crushed to death by the fall ofa tree and MT John Alcorn. of Moon township, received severe wounds on his head and shoulders by the fall of limb.

 The Philadelphia papers mention that at the late session of the yearly meeting of Friends in that city, three thousand dollars were ap- propriated towards defraying the expenses of certain free people of colour from North Car olina. to Liberia, Hayti, and the free states,as they may prefer

 The American Trade with China last year amounted to $B,949, ,542, The commerce be- tween China and South America was double what it had been the year previous.

 At the Merrimack company's mils,in Low cit, Mass. eleven thousond yards of cloth $ Manut tactured daity most of which is printed for calicoes.

 The Editors of the Bostnn Recorder and Telegraph have issued proposals for publish Ing weekly paper for the special use oi " AI~1 Al

He planted four acres twOswith seed in iCs natural state, and two with seed soaked as above. Contrary to his fears, the lat- ter came up four days earlier than the for mer it was not injured in the least by worms or birds, while one half of the hills on the other two acres required to be plan ted second time. If the seed being im- Pregnated with the salts is not injured, if it will grow as well as seed not soaked-- the experiment can easily be made wheth- CT the salts will preserve # from birds and worms, by exposing quant;+y of it where worms, squirrels and birds can have access it. 1t is worthy an experiment of the kind, and we trust some of our agricultu- ralists will give it trial, for their own, as we'll as the public good.

 The severe cold with which we were visited on the first inst. is accounted for, from the fact, that the late storm was one of snow at the north. The papers inform us that the whole range of the CattskiIl mountains arc covered with snow to con- siderable depth. Cloaks are not usually needed on the first day of May ;-but this year few persons appeared to feel com fortable without one. We have reason to fear that this change in the weather from what it was three weeks since, will destroy peaches if not sundry other kinds of fruit.

 Fir.-The inhabitants of this quiet village were on Tuesday evening last aroused from their cosltations by the alarming cry of fire. This was an almost entirely new sound to a great majority of the citizens; for however it may be with other villages of similar size, which have engines to extinguish fire, and of course can afford to have them often, we, be- ing destitute of like safe guards, and depend ing solely upon Etna and Protection insur- ance policies, have heretofore. at least for several years, seen no larger flame than is made by a shaving bonfire But we have di- gressed; as above stated, there was on Tues day evening fire no less real than the burn ing of house. How it took fire is the ques- ton; Tuesday was d cold day, and had the tenement been inhabited by bipeds we might kaye concluded that the room had been over- heated to keep them warm; but such an expla- nation will not answer, for we are told that there has becn no fire near the building for several weeks except that which "levelled it with the dust" We must therefore conclude. that the said house possessed certain inherent ignitible qualities, winch kindly refrained from acting while it stood in the immediate vicinity of better buildings; but on its being removed to a new location, where it could burn without alarming its neighbours, it peace ably took itself out of the way. Damage,- to the owner SloO,OO.

 So great IS the dearth of news at the pres ent time, that after looking over fifty or sixty papers from different parts of the country, we can scarcely find sufficient suitable matter to fill our sheet. We seized our last New York and Boston papers. with eagerness, ho- ping to find two or three columns filled with "latest and important intelligence from Flu rope;" but here we were disappointed. No thing of importance is copyed from English and French papers. except the " Fashions for May," and sundry theatrical notices. How ever important such articles may he to the ci- ty gentry, we care not enough about them to induce us to read more than the caption, and take it for granted that our readers are some what likeminded. Fer want of more imme- diately interesting matter, the presidential question fills pretty large share of every i'm portant political paper; certain of these arti- cles we feel strongly inclined to copy, in or der to be in keeping with our contemporaries. The Morgan affair is by no means forgotten nor should it be until some of the darkness which surrounds it is expelled; but we live out of its influence, aud have ourselves said enough on the subject, until we can say MOrpa n iS alive n or tho r,onrdarors oc tt a
